Term.Name: 2D Video
Term.Definition: Classic two-dimensional (2D) video material.

Term.Name: SD
Term.Definition: Standard definition

Term.Name: HD
Term.Definition: High definition

Term.Name: Up-sampled from SD
Term.Definition: Video up-sampled from standard definition source material.

Term.Name: UHD
Term.Definition: Ultra-high definition

Term.Name: 4K
Term.Definition: 4K UHDTV, also referred to as 2160p (with a resolution of 3840 pixels wide by 2160 pixels tall).

Term.Name: 8K
Term.Definition: 8K UHDTV, also referred to as 4320p (with a resolution of 7680 pixels wide by 4320 pixels tall).

Term.Name: Plano-Stereoscopic Video
Term.Definition: Three-dimensional (3D), plano-stereoscopic video material.

Term.Name: Frame-Compatible 3D
Term.Definition: 3D video material, encoded in a frame-compatible way by splitting up frame contents into 2 areas, one for each eye.

Term.Name: Side-by-Side 3D Format
Term.Definition: 3D video material, encoded in a way that each component plane of the decoded frames contains a side-by-side packing arrangement of corresponding planes of two constituent frames.

Term.Name: Top-and-Bottom 3D Format
Term.Definition: 3D video material, encoded in a way that each component plane of the decoded frames contains a top-bottom packing arrangement of corresponding planes of two constituent frames.

Term.Name: Checkerboard-based 3D Format
Term.Definition: 3D video material, encoded in a way that each component plane of the decoded frames contains a "checkerboard" based interleaving of corresponding planes of two constituent frames.

Term.Name: Column-based interleaving 3D Format
Term.Definition: 3D video material, encoded in a way that each component plane of the decoded frames contains a column based interleaving of corresponding planes of two constituent frames.

Term.Name: Row-based interleaving 3D Format
Term.Definition: 3D video material, encoded in a way that each component plane of the decoded frames contains a row based interleaving of corresponding planes of two constituent frames.

Term.Name: Temporal interleaving 3D Format
Term.Definition: 3D video material, encoded in a way that the component planes of the decoded frames in output order form a temporal interleaving of alternating first and second constituent frames.

Term.Name: Service-Compatible 3D
Term.Definition: 3D video material, encoded in a service-compatible way, thereby offering the possibility to devices to extract 2D images from the 3D content.

Term.Name: MVC Stereo profile
Term.Definition: 3D video material, encoded in a MVC stereo profile - compliant way (i.e. BlueRay).

Term.Name: Frame-Packing 3D Format
Term.Definition: 3D video material, encoded in a way wherein a single frame consists of two sub-frames meant for each eye, combined into a single frame using either the Top-and-Bottom 3D or Side-by-Side 3D formats without any halving of the vertical or horizontal resolution of individual sub-frames in each format respectively.

Term.Name: Multiview Autoscopic Video
Term.Definition: Multi-dimensional video material, encoded in a multiscopic way, consisting of e.g. an array of feeds produced by several cameras (e.g. 5)

Term.Name: Downwards-compatible multiscopic Video
Term.Definition: Multi-dimensional video material, encoded in a way that it is downwards compatible to stereoscopic devices.

Term.Name: Non-downwards-compatible multiscopic 3D
Term.Definition: Multi-dimensional video material, encoded in a way that it is not compatible to stereoscopic devices, therefore requiring support for more than stereoscopic rendering.

Term.Name: Holographic Video
Term.Definition: Multi-dimensional holographic video material.

Term.Name: Holographic 3D
Term.Definition: 3D video material, created and encoded especially for holographic 3D rendering devices.
